Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a new cultural movement where everyday people tinker with concepts in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics), simply for the purpose of satisfying creativity and curiosity. This "maker movement" is powered by the wide availability of low-cost electronics and manufacturing tools, which allow amateur makers to create interactive objects while exploring scientific phenomena. Such environments have great potential to engage people with STEM concepts and activities while empowering individuals to find creative solutions to complex and personally meaningful issues. However, in these learning environments, frequently students' focus is more on completing a technical project rather than comprehending scientific concepts. While some learning does happen in such contexts, a significant portion of maker activities may include following a list of instructions and trusting that they are going to result into a functional project. In this project an emerging technology, Augmented Reality (AR), is investigated as a means to transform the STEM maker movement by making challenging concepts accessible to students. Many invisible phenomena are involved in maker space activities (e.g., the flow of electricity, the interaction of magnetic fields, or the movement of air pressure waves). Augmented Reality headsets, such as the Microsoft Hololens, allow students to see virtual "holograms" in the physical world. This project investigates the impact of design activities where learners can visualize and interact with the hidden forces involved in their projects, such as electrons, magnetic fields, light or radio waves, or to visualize the inner workings of physical components such as microchips and sensors. This proposal explores how a new generation of maker spaces can be enhanced by augmented reality technologies to create learning environments that enable making with understanding.

This project augments traditional student activities in maker spaces using augmented reality (AR) technology, and investigates whether this intervention 1) increases learning gains, 2) facilitates deeper conceptual discussion among students, and 3) modifies student conceptions of the observed phenomena. An example activity includes building a speaker from scratch (in which amplified electrical signals are converted into magnetic fields), or programming a micro-controller to make decisions based on the readings of multiple sensors. Such activities are enhanced by the use of AR technology, as the system overlays a representation the invisible phenomena (flow of electrons, magnetic forces, sensor values, snippets of code, etc.) directly on top of the relevant physical components. Research involves conducting systematic empirical studies to compare the usefulness of AR-based learning vs. traditional non-AR approaches, and follow-up studies to identify the affordances for collaborative learning. The project will employ traditional quantitative and qualitative measures, along with novel methods from the field of multi-modal learning analytics to understand and classify students' behaviors across conditions. This work will 1) contribute to our understanding of how student education of STEM concepts can be enhanced by new technologies such as augmented reality, 2) contribute a set of reusable modules to visualize and simulate the invisible phenomena that are commonly encountered in maker activities, and 3) produce guidelines to help the design of innovative learning environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Augmenting physical activities with digital information is a compelling way to scaffold students? understanding of invisible concepts in STEM. It can decrease the cognitive load of integrating different representations, allow students to interact with those concepts in real-time, connect students? everyday experiences with formal concepts in STEM and let them receive immediate feedback. Augmented Reality (AR), however, may be detrimental by distracting students from reflecting and deeply internalizing the concepts taught. In this project, we studied the effects of AR technology on collaborative learning of STEM concepts in makerspace environments. The goal was to impact the maker culture by generating new kinds of making experiences that enable students to effectively learn by interacting with invisible phenomena. By having student makers ?see? and better understand the invisible forces that they are manipulating (electricity, radio waves, sensors, ...), this project aspires to move students from merely doing, to actually understanding how complex systems work. 

 

We developed several augmented reality systems to better understand the benefits and drawbacks of this technology for STEM learning. In phase 1 of the project, we built a collaborative learning application for teaching physics of electromagnetism, where participants can interact with a physical speaker and see AR visualizations. In phase 2, we developed another augmented reality collaborative learning application where collaborators learn about robots and sensor values. In phase 3, we explored the impact of an augmented reality tool for visualizing electronic signals in a naturalistic environment; we compared it to a non-augmented reality tool we designed (which is more portable and lower-tech) for achieving the same goal. In each phase, we conducted a research study and analyzed data, generating 5 publications about the effects of AR on learning and collaboration in the context of physics education (study 1); 1 publication about the effects of AR on learning and collaboration in the context of robot programming (study 2); and 2 publications about the effects of these tools in a makerspace classroom context (study 3).

 

From the three research studies, we collected evidence that AR technology has the potential to support collaborative learning of STEM concepts. More specifically, we found that: 

  • AR technology can help students learn and understand 3D structures for otherwise invisible phenomena, can help students understand relationships between system components, and can help students transfer knowledge to other contexts

  • AR technology can improve student perceptions of self-efficacy and engagement

  • AR technology can improve knowledge transfer between imbalanced students

  • AR technology can improve collaboration grounding, increase contributions of weaker learners, and reduce the effects of dominance

  • AR technology is still novel, and learners may experience novelty effects causing temporary increases in engagement and misperceptions of own learning

  • AR technology can be detrimental by generating tunnel vision effects, whereby AR-enabled learners pay attention to visual information more than tactile information

  • AR technology may pose barriers to entry due to poor portability, lack of familiarity, and high costs

 

In summary, this project made research and product contributions towards augmenting open-ended learning environments such as makerspaces. We designed, built, tested and empirically evaluated AR technology in laboratory and naturalistic settings. We found that AR has the potential to impact learners? understanding of complex concepts, their attitude, and collaboration with peers. These findings have implications for STEM formal and informal education. By educating students about invisible phenomena in physics and computer science, and by providing them with knowledge and abilities for constructing physical-digital projects, our findings suggest that AR technology can positively impact makers by increasing conceptual understanding of the invisible forces they work with, support collaboration in small communities, and positively impact their self-efficacy and engagement in STEM domains. A final contribution was to produce design guidelines on how Augmented Reality can facilitate hands-on learning of STEM concepts.
